final_report.root_cause: The geo service process (hotel-reserv-geo) was using an incorrect/unconfigured MongoDB connection string and attempted to connect to mongodb-geo:27777, but the mongodb-geo Service listens on port 27017. The geo pod's container spec does not provide any MongoDB connection environment variables (e.g., MONGO_URL/DB_HOST), so the application fell back to a default/incorrect DB URL (mongodb-geo:27777). The failed connection produced "no reachable servers" in the DB client, which triggered a panic in main.initializeDatabase and caused the pod to CrashLoopBackOff.
affected_resources: Deployment/geo (all pods in the geo deployment)
final_report.evidence_summary: 1) Container logs from hotel-reserv-geo show: "Read database URL: mongodb-geo:27777", "Initializing DB connection...", then "no reachable servers" and a panic stacktrace pointing to main.initializeDatabase (db.go:26). 2) kubectl describe of the geo pod shows the container environment only contains JAEGER_SAMPLE_RATIO (no MONGO_URL/DB_HOST or DB connection args). 3) kubectl get service mongodb-geo shows the Service exists and exposes port 27017 (targetPort 27017). 4) Image pull succeeded (yinfangchen/geo:app3) and the container repeatedly exits with code 2 and restart counts consistent with CrashLoopBackOff. Together these demonstrate the geo app used an incorrect port (27777) and lacked correct configuration to reach MongoDB at 27017, causing the startup panic.
final_report.investigation_summary: Priority-1 log collection revealed the proximate failure: DB client "no reachable servers" and an immediate panic during DB initialization. Priority-2 inspection of pod spec and Service showed the geo pod had no DB connection env vars while the mongodb-geo Service existed on port 27017. Correlating these findings shows a configuration omission/mismatch on the geo side: the application used a default (or baked-in) DB URL with port 27777 rather than connecting to the Service at 27017. No evidence indicated MongoDB itself was down; the Service and backing pod exist. Based on available evidence, no further tasks are required to identify the root cause.

- Pick the minimum tool set (ideally one or two calls) needed to prove or disprove the hypothesis. Over-broad tool lists are rejected.

- Priority 1 is the most direct epicenter investigation. Immediately after that, schedule the connection-check tasks described above; treat them as top-tier because they frequently surface misconfigurations.
